title: Warning after counterfeited $100 notes found in South Australia
text:
An urgent warning has been issued after a series of convincing counterfeited $100 notes were found in circulation.

Alarms were raised after three fake notes were discovered in Riverland, South Australia last week.

Business owners reported the fake money to police after noticing some of the notes had used liquid paper and could be easily torn.

South Australian police warned business owners after three counterfeited notes (pictured) were discovered in the Riverland region last week

One business owner said he initially thought the note had just been damaged or was old

Baker, Scott Jones who received the fake cash last Saturday said he initially took no notice of the money.

'It wasn't until another $100 note went in on top of it that it caught the staff's attention,' Mr Jones told ABC radio.

He said he thought the note had just been damaged or was very old.

His wife had seen information online about counterfeiting which prompted their suspicions.

'It's maybe one or two millimetres shorter width-wise, a very slight colour variation. It has the window like all modern Australian notes,' Mr Jones said.

'It's not paper, it's printed on some form of plastic type material, like normal notes. The material's slightly textured so it does feel legitimate.'

Mr Jones then found the mistake was lying along the bottom of the note, saying the counterfeited cash didn't 'perfectly make a five-pointed star'.

A shop assistant noticed the money was fake when they were able to tear it (file image)

Police were first notified when a counterfeited note using liquid paper was spotted outside a supermarket last Tuesday.

On Saturday another incident arose after a shop assistant noticed a $100 note they just received 'felt funny'.

The cashier said the note was able to be easily ripped which alerted them it was fake.

Police have urged business owners to compare any notes they believe are fake with ones that are known to be genuine.

Anybody who believes they have received counterfeited money are advised to contact police.
description: Alarms were raised after three fake notes were discovered in Riverland, South Australia last week.
authors: Eliza Mcphee For Daily Mail Australia
